page.title: 13Local History_Country House.
page.content: {Newton Surmaville}is a beautiful Jacobean country house of 3 stories constructed of local Ham stone. It was built between 1608_1612 for Robert Harbin and son and has remained in the family ever since. There are 15 main rooms,many still have their original oak panelling, others are hung with tapestries. In addition there are attics with 9 rooms and a kitchen wing with 8 rooms, 32 rooms in all. 3 of the original oak four poster beds. There are a large number of paintings about the house, over 50 being in one room. The grounds extend to 400 acres including Newton and Stoford Farms. It is a typical Somerset country house of the period,its'square windows and ornate chimneys were copied from nearby Montacute House.{The father of {the present occupant translated the {Somerset Domesday book.
